questions.text: A pathology student asks you, about advice on the disposal of the discarded formalin from a specimen container. You would advise her to dispose of it, in which of the following containers?
questions.solution:
Discarded formalin and other chemical liquid waste are disposed of in the yellow container.

questions.text: You are performing an emergency appendicectomy in a COVID-19 positive patient. After surgery, in which bin would you dispose of the N95 mask?
questions.solution:
The N95 masks used by healthcare workers, while treating COVID-19 positive patients, must be disposed of in the yellow bin.

Related Pearl: Biomedical Waste (BMW) Management -COVID 19

In addition to the current BMW Management rules, the following measures are proposed

  • To report opening/operation of COVID 19 Ward/ICU/Lab/Collection Centre to SPCB (State Pollution Control Board) and CBWTF (Common Biomedical Waste Treatment Facility) in that area
  • Dedicated sanitation workers deputed only to collect COVID 19 BMW
  • It is mandatory for all BMW bags and containers from COVID 19 areas to carry "COVID 19 WASTE" label
  • Keep separate colour coded bins with foot operated lids
  • The inner and outer surfaces of these containers must be disinfected daily with 1% sodium hypochlorite solution
  • To ensure no leaks, double layers (2 bags) are used

questions.text: Which of the following items is least suited for disposal in a landfill?
questions.solution:
Among the given options, the urinary bag, which is a plastic waste is the least suitable for disposal in a landfill. 

Plastic wastes such as urinary bags are disposed of in the red bin and should not be sent to landfill. Plastic waste can be sent for diesel, fuel oil and road making.

Waste sharps including metals can be disposed of by autoclaving or dry heat sterilisation ---> shredding/ mutilation/ encapsulation in metal containers or cement concrete ---> final disposal in a sanitary landfill or designated concrete waste sharp pit or be sent to approved iron foundries.

questions.text: According to biomedical waste management, what is the appropriate method of treatment for the instrument shown below?
questions.solution:
The appropriate method of treatment of the intraosseous needle, shown in the image, is autoclaving.

Needles, syringes with fixed needles, needles from needle tip cutters or burners, scalpels, blades, or any other contaminated sharp object that may cause punctures and cuts are disposed of in white, translucent, puncture-proof, and leak-proof containers. They are treated by autoclaving/ dry heat sterilization followed by - shredding/mutilation/encapsulation and later sent to iron foundries/sanitary landfills.

Autoclaving is a method of heat sterilization. The autoclave is a device that uses steam under pressure to sterilize linen, instruments, laboratory ware, media, pharmaceutical products, aqueous solutions, surgical instruments, cardiac catheters, and implants.

The image given below shows an autoclave.

The biomedical waste management rule applies to all those who collect, receive, store, dispose, and treat biomedical waste. The wastes are categorized and segregated at the point of generation of waste. A color coding system with 4 colors namely yellow, red, white, and blue is used for waste segregation. 

The segregated waste is then treated by various methods. They are:

  • Incineration (Option B)- this is a dry oxidation process done using high temperatures. The types are rotary kiln, pyrolytic incinerator, and single chamber incinerator.  
  • Chemical disinfection (Option D)- chemicals are added to waste to kill or inactivate the microorganisms. Mostly used for treating liquid wastes. 
  • Wet and dry thermal treatment - shredded infectious waste is exposed to high temperature, high-pressure steam and it resembles an autoclave sterilization process. 
  • Microwave irradiation (Option A) - microorganisms are killed using high-frequency microwaves. Its efficiency should be checked routinely.

Later disposed of by -

  • Iron foundries/sanitary landfill
  • Inertization: Waste is mixed with cement to reduce toxicity.

questions.text: Which of the following methods is not effective for disinfection of sputum of patients?
questions.solution:
Chlorhexidine is not used to disinfect sputum.

Sputum can be disinfected by:

  • Autoclaving or boiling - if a considerable amount of sputum is present (e.g. in TB hospitals)
  • 5% cresol - patients are asked to spit in a sputum cup half-filled with cresol
  • Burning - for samples received in gauze or paper handkerchiefs

questions.text: A middle-aged man presents to the medicine OPD with cough and hemoptysis. The sputum culture done on the culture media is shown below. What is the usual method of sterilization used for this medium?
questions.solution:
The given image shows the Lowenstein-Jensen medium. The medium is sterilized by inspissation.

Inspissation is used for the sterilization of heat-labile culture media containing eggs or serum. This method of sterilization involves heating at 80–85 °C for 30 minutes on 3 consecutive days. Another medium for which this method is used is Loeffler's serum.

Lowenstein–Jensen medium is commonly used, egg-based, selective culture media used to cultivate Mycobacterium tuberculosis. Loeffler's serum slope is an enriched medium for the growth of Corynebacterium diphtheria.

Other Options:

Option B: Pasteurization - Milk is heated at either 63°C for 30 minutes (the holder method) or at 72°C for 15–20 seconds (the flash process), followed by cooling quickly to 13°C or lower. 

Option C: Autoclaving is a method of sterilization by moist heat.

Option D: Hot air oven is a method of sterilization by dry heat.

Moist heat causes coagulation and denaturation of proteins, while dry heat causes oxidation and charring of proteins. Hence not preferred for egg-containing culture media like the Lowenstein-Jensen medium.

questions.text: The equipment shown below is used for the sterilization of all of the following except:
questions.solution:
The given image shows an autoclave.  It is not used to sterilize endoscopes because most of them are heat-sensitive. 

Autoclaving is a method of heat sterilization using steam under pressure. The temperature is kept between 108oC to 147oC. It is used to sterilize linen, instruments, laboratory ware, media, pharmaceutical products, aqueous solutions, surgical instruments, cardiac catheters, and implants.

Endoscopes are cleaned using liquid chemical sterilizing agents such as orthophthaldehyde as it has bactericidal properties and is quick, safe and effective.`

Other equipments used in sterilization include:

Hot air oven- The objects undergo a holding period of 160oC for two hours to sterilize glassware, forceps, scissors, scalpels, swabs, and some pharmaceutical products such as liquid paraffin, dusting powder.

 

UV sterilization: Ultraviolet radiation is used to disinfect enclosed areas mainly biosafety cabinets in laboratories, operation theatres, and laboratories. The given image shows UV sterilization in a biosafety cabinet.

 

Incineration : Terminal sterilisation for destroying biomedical waste such as human anatomical waste and plastics such as PVC and polythene.

questions.text: Which of the following is used to clean a blood spill in the emergency room?
questions.solution:
Sodium hypochlorite, a compound of chlorine, is the best disinfectant for surface blood spills. It is used with a concentration of 0.5-5%.

If the spill contains large amounts of blood or body fluids, clean the visible matter with disposable absorbent material and discard the contaminated materials in appropriate, labeled containment. 

A 1:10–1:100 dilution of 5.25%–6.15% sodium hypochlorite (i.e., household bleach) or an EPA-registered tuberculocidal disinfectant has been recommended for decontaminating blood spills. 

Phenolic compounds (option B), Quaternary ammonium compounds (option C) and Alcoholic compounds (option D) are not effective in blood spills.

questions.text: An on-site waste treatment and disposal facility should be built in a hospital if the nearest common biomedical treatment facility is:
questions.solution:
According to biomedical waste management rules of 2016, healthcare establishments shall establish an on-site treatment and disposal facility only when a common biomedical treatment facility (CBMWTF) is more than 75 km away.

According to these rules, biomedical waste (BMW) from healthcare facilities is to be transported to a CMBWTF. The establishment of CBMWTF reduces the need for transport and cost of treatment/ kg of BMW.

questions.text: You are sending pharmaceutical waste from the hospital for inertization. What percentages of cement and lime are added for this method of biomedical waste treatment?
questions.solution:
The percentages of cement and lime used for inertization are 15% and 15% respectively.

Inertization is the process of mixing biomedical waste with non-toxic substances to reduce the toxicity of the waste and reduce the contamination of groundwater. It is most commonly used for incineration ash with high metal content. The typical composition of the inertization mixture is:

  • 65% - pharmaceutical waste
  • 15% - cement
  • 15% - lime
  • 5% - water

A homogeneous mass is formed and cubes or pellets are produced on-site and then transported to suitable storage sites.

questions.text: Waste sharps are taken from the autoclave after sterilization. Which waste treatment method would be employed next?
questions.solution:
Waste sharps are treated by mutilation or shredding. Shredding of waste is done to reduce the volume of waste and to increase the extent of contact.

Waste sharps are treated by autoclaving or dry heat sterilization, followed by mutilation or encapsulation.

questions.text: Which of the following is used for the disinfection of bins that store COVID 19 waste?
questions.solution:
Sodium hypochlorite is used for the disinfection of bins that store COVID 19 waste.

According to the Central pollution control board(CPCB) guidelines, daily disinfection of both the inner and outer surfaces of the containers/ bins/ trolleys used for storage of COVID 19 waste should be done with 1% sodium hypochlorite solution.

Option B: Methyl alcohol is useful in cleaning cabinets and incubators.

Option C: Isopropyl alcohol is used to disinfect clinical thermometers. It is also used as a skin antiseptic at concentrations of 60-90% in water.

Option D: Glutaraldehyde is useful in the sterilization of bronchoscopes, cystoscopes, plastic endotracheal tubes, rubber anesthetic tubes, and polythene tubings.

Related Pearl: Biomedical Waste (BMW) Management -COVID 19

In addition to the current BMW Management rules, the following measures are proposed

  • To report opening/operation of COVID 19 Ward/ICU/Lab/Collection Centre to SPCB (State Pollution Control Board) and CBWTF (Common Biomedical Waste Treatment Facility) in that area
  • Dedicated sanitation workers deputed only to collect COVID 19 BMW
  • It is mandatory for all BMW bags and containers from COVID 19 areas to carry "COVID 19 WASTE" label
  • Keep separate colour coded bins with foot operated lids
  • The inner and outer surfaces of these containers must be disinfected daily with 1% sodium hypochlorite solution
  • To ensure no leaks, double layers (2 bags) are used

questions.text: What proportion of healthcare waste is hazardous waste?
questions.solution:
15% of health care waste is hazardous waste. It may be infectious, toxic, or radioactive in nature. The remaining 85% is general, non-hazardous waste.

Bio-medical waste means any waste that is generated during:

  • Diagnosis, treatment, or immunization of human beings or animals 
  • Research activities pertaining thereto
  • Production or testing of biologicals

Bio-medical waste is handled as per the Bio-medical Waste Management Rules, 2016. However, these rules do not apply to the following:

  • Radioactive wastes
  • Hazardous chemicals
  • Solid wastes
  • Lead-acid batteries
  • Hazardous wastes
  • e-Waste
  • Hazardous microorganisms

questions.text:
Which of the following should not be incinerated?
  1. Sharps and waste with heavy metals
  2. Reactive chemical waste
  3. Specimens of microorganisms
  4. Pressurized gas containers
  5. Live or attenuated vaccines
questions.solution:
Specimens of microorganisms and live or attenuated vaccines can be incinerated.

Wastes that should not be incinerated are:

  • Sharps
  • Pressurized gas containers
  • Reactive chemical waste
  • Waste with heavy metals like mercury and cadmium
  • PVC
  • Photographic or radiographic waste

questions.text: An HIV-positive man is brought to you following an accident. How would you discard his blood-soaked dressing material?

choices.text: Pour 1% hypochlorite on the dressing material and send for incineration
Pour 5% hypochlorite on the dressing material and send for incineration
Put the dressing material directly in an appropriate bag and send for incineration
Pour 10% non chlorinated chemicals on the dressing material and send for incineration

questions.solution:
The blood-soaked dressing material should be disposed of in a non-chlorinated yellow bag and sent for incineration. Pretreatment is not a requisite for incinerating soiled waste.

  • Other infectious plastic and liquid wastes 
  • Laboratory cultures, stocks, or specimens of microorganisms
  • Live or attenuated vaccines
  • Human and animal cell cultures used in research

questions.text: While collecting blood for samples, you have spilled some on the floor. What would be the immediate next step?

choices.text: Call the infection control team of the hospital

questions.solution:
The immediate next step in this scenario is to clean the spilled blood with absorbable material.

This absorbable material is then discarded in the yellow bin. Following this, sodium hypochlorite solution is used to decontaminate the surface. The concentrations of sodium hypochlorite used are: 

  • < 10 mL blood spill - 1:100 dilution to decontaminate non-porous surfaces
  • > 10 mL blood spill or culture spill - 1:10 dilution for the first application, followed by 1:100 dilution
